title: Prayer Against Enemies
shortSummary: Psalm 83 is a fervent prayer by Asaph calling on God not to remain silent in the face of a conspiracy by Israel’s enemies who seek to destroy the nation. The psalmist recalls past divine victories over Israel’s foes and petitions God to act decisively, demonstrating His sovereignty and protecting His people.
timeline: Likely composed during the divided monarchy period of Israel, possibly c. 900-700 BC, reflecting ongoing threats from neighboring nations hostile to Israel.

keyCharacters.name: Asaph
keyCharacters.description: The psalmist and worship leader who composes this prayer, calling on God to defend His people.

keyCharacters.name: Edom
keyCharacters.description: A neighboring nation descended from Esau, listed among the enemies conspiring against Israel.

keyCharacters.name: Ishmaelites
keyCharacters.description: Descendants of Ishmael, representing Arab tribes allied against Israel.

keyCharacters.name: Amalek
keyCharacters.description: A traditional enemy of Israel, known for persistent hostility and opposition.

definitions.definition: A liturgical or musical pause in the psalm, possibly indicating reflection or emphasis.
Tents or dwellings; here referring to the settled tribes or nations allied against Israel.
United in a league or alliance for a common purpose, especially hostile action.
A term referring to God's chosen people, Israel, who are protected and known intimately by God.

outline.heading: Urgent Plea for Divine Intervention
outline.description: The psalmist implores God not to be silent or inactive while enemies rise up in tumult and pride against Him and His people.

outline.heading: Description of the Enemy Conspiracy
outline.description: A detailed listing of the nations and tribes united in a plot to annihilate Israel, emphasizing their shared intent to erase Israel’s identity.

outline.heading: Recall of Past Divine Deliverances
outline.description: The psalmist calls on God to act as He did against Midian, Sisera, and other enemies in Israel’s history, invoking memories of God’s mighty judgments.

outline.heading: Prayer for God’s Judgment and Vindication
outline.description: A passionate petition for God to destroy the enemies, cause them shame, and reveal His supremacy so that all may know He alone is the Most High.

application: Trust God to defend His people and act on behalf of His children when facing opposition or persecution.
Pray fervently and specifically for God’s justice against those who seek to harm the church or believers.
Remember and meditate on God’s past faithfulness and victories as encouragement in times of trouble.
Seek God’s name and glory above all, recognizing His sovereignty over all the earth.

keyVerses.text: Keep not thou silence, O God: hold not thy peace, and be not still, O God.
keyVerses.significance: This opening verse sets the urgent tone of the psalm, expressing the believer’s cry for God’s active intervention.

keyVerses.text: They have said, Come, and let us cut them off from being a nation; that the name of Israel may be no more in remembrance.
keyVerses.significance: Highlights the deadly intent of Israel’s enemies to erase God’s chosen people from history.

keyVerses.text: That men may know that thou, whose name alone is JEHOVAH, art the most high over all the earth.
keyVerses.significance: Affirms the ultimate purpose of God’s deliverance: to reveal His exclusive supremacy and holiness to all nations.
